summary: This compilation from 19811982 by the Review of Ghana Law reports on personal injury awards from various High Court decisions across Ghana, primarily arising from road accidents, workplace incidents, and police actions. The cases cover fatal injuries, multiple traumas, and specific bodily injuries (arm, wrist, spine, leg). Awards are itemized into general damages (pain and suffering, loss of amenities), special damages (medical, transport, funeral), and pecuniary losses (loss of current and future earnings, dependency). Courts considered factors such as the victim's age, occupation, income, dependants, likelihood of remarriage (in dependency claims), degree of permanent disability, and specific life impacts like loss of consortium or inability to work. Notably, FLETCHER v. OPPONG involved a police shooting with a high award of over 250,000, while DAGARTI v. STATE GOLD MINING CORPORATION addressed a mining accident leading to paraplegia. The methodology often included 'years' purchase' for future earnings and explicit recognition of mental distress and cosmetic deformity.
verdict: Plaintiffs awarded damages in all listed cases.
citations: BAAH v. GHANA COCOA MARKETING BOARD
BROOKMAN-AMISSAH v. OWUSU BENTUM CONSTRUCTION LTD.
OMARI-SASU v. AFFUL (headteacher case and judge case separately cited but same name; treated as one citation for indexing purposes here with note of dual claims)
rationaleHighlights: Awards based on age, earning capacity, dependants, and extent of disability
Future loss of earnings calculated via 'years' purchase' method
Funeral and medical expenses reimbursed as special damages
Mental distress recognized for close family members in fatal cases
Permanent disability percentages used to scale compensation
Consideration of likelihood of remarriage affecting dependency claims
confidenceNotes: Multiple cases are aggregated in the source document under a summary report format; individual case details are accurate as presented, but procedural or appellate context is limited. Citation OMARI-SASU v. AFFUL appears twice for different plaintiffs (a headteacher and a judge), likely a typographical error or misattribution in source.
